ALT Text: The ‚ÄúActivity‚Äù tab in Microsoft Teams is shown , with a list showing on the left one activity ‚ÄúNew tasks in SAP S/4HANA ‚Äì There is 1 new task for you ‚Äì ToDos‚Äù and on the right embedded within Teams the screen from My Inbox, showing the header data plus a list of Items and Bidders, and action buttons at the bottom for Approve, Reject, Show Log, Claim, Forward and Suspend.

 See it in action here:

  • Video: To-Dos in Microsoft Teams (1:00 min.)

 In addition to being able to process To-Dos for tasks directly in Microsoft Teams, you can also process To-Dos for Business Situations directly in Microsoft Teams.

This means that you get notified in your Teams activity feed about new Business Situations, and you can process Business Situations in place, without having to leave Teams, as you can see in Figure 18.

Figure 18: To-Dos for Business Situations are available via Activities in Microsoft Teams. Alt Text: Two screenshots are shown, the top one shows an row of Situation cards in My Home, the bottom one shows the Activity view in Teams, with the activity ‚ÄúSituations in SAP S/4HANA‚Äù and sub-text ‚ÄúThere are 9 situations for you‚Äù selected on the left, and the right two thirds of the screen showing a list with the same situations as shown in My Home.

To enable this, you need to install the SAP S/4HANA for Microsoft Teams app.

For further information:

  • Documentation: Integrating Microsoft Teams.

Contact Cards Show Contact‚Äôs Availability Status

Since FPS02 of the 2023 release, users can initiate a chat or call with Microsoft Teams directly from a contact card. I featured this in my previous blog post, look at Figure 5 there for two examples:

  • SAP User Experience Q4/2024 News for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2023.

Now, with the 2025 release, this has been enhanced to show the availability status of the contact as provided by Teams.

Share as Card via Adaptive Card-based Loop Component

We now offer the option to enable embedding of interactive cards with information and actions from SAP S/4HANA Cloud and SAP S/4HANA directly into Microsoft Teams chats. The data and actions are only shown to users with the necessary authorizations. Technically this is done via adaptive card-based Loop component, for applications built with SAP Fiori elements. Figure 19 shows an example.

Figure 19: An example of an adaptive card embedded in a Teams chat. Alt Text: A screenshot of a chat, with a request text to Megan at the top, followed by a URL to access the app, and then a card showing a purchase contract, with the text Quantity Contract as a hyperlink, along with 9 further fields from the contract. At the bottom clickable buttons ‚ÄúCopy‚Äù and ‚ÄúWithdraw from Approval‚Äù.

 Find out more, including how to set it up:

  • Integrating the Share: Microsoft Teams > As Card ‚Äì Authentication-Enabled Option (documentation).

UX Improvements in Details

As I never tire of saying: the details matter if you want to provide a great UX! We continue to work on these details, which can often result in higher satisfaction for users. With the 2025 release, we bring you a large number of improvements, as outlined in the following subsections. Note that we have four interesting ones related to working with tables towards the end of this section.

New Options for Filtering Dates (Semantic Date Range)

We have two new features here:

  • We now offer the semantic date range also for selecting dates in the table settings dialog, if you want to define a specific filter on a given field in the table. (Note that the table settings dialog allows you to define filters on all the fields in the table, irrespective of which fields appear in the filter bar at the top of the screen).
  • I‚Äôm pleased to say that, on request of many users, we now provide the option to define filters on date fields for the ‚ÄúLast X days/weeks/months/‚Ä¶ to date‚Äù as well as the ‚ÄúNext X days/weeks/months/‚Ä¶ to date‚Äù, where users can specify the number ‚ÄúX‚Äù.

An example of how tricky such seemingly simple things can be: if, on December 11th, you choose ‚ÄúLast 2 months to date‚Äù, do you mean the period from November 1st to December 11th, which would be up to the current date but not a full two months, or do you mean ‚Äúthe last two full months‚Äù, i.e. October 1st to November 30th? Since both make sense, the selection screen gives users the option to choose, with the default being the ‚Äúfull month‚Äù case, described as ‚Äúexclude current period‚Äù, as you can see in Figure 20.

Column Size Persisted in Flexible Column Layout

When users open up an application which uses the Flexible Column Layout, it will now remember where the user had placed the separator last time, rather than putting it in the default position. Figure 21 shows an example where at the top you see the default position, and below you see the separator moved to the right slightly, so that all the text is visible in the table on the left. Next time the app is opened, the separator will open in the same place.

Figure 21: Flexible Column Layout now remembers the previously used column width. The image at the top shows the default column width, the image below shows the last column width the user chose. Alt Text: two images of Manage Cost Centers application is shown, the upper one has the separator bar between the list on the left and the details on the right further to the left than the image on the right.

All Data Dictionary Help Texts Available to Users

This feature was requested by many customers, and I am happy to announce that it is now available: all the help texts for individual fields which are stored in the back-end data dictionary are now available to users using the built-in help, powered by SAP Companion. In other words, users of SAP Fiori apps have access to the same help texts as were shown with the classic UIs such as SAP GUI. You can see an example in Figure 22.

Figure 22: Data Dictionary help texts now available in SAP Fiori apps. Alt Text: The Manage Purchase Contracts screen is shown, with question marks next to all fields and column headers. On the right the Help Topics are listed, with the Purchase Contract Number selected. Next to the corresponding column header a popover shows the definition text.

Documentation of Keyboard Shortcuts within Applications

Power users are often quicker when only using the keyboard, rather than switching back and forth between keyboard and mouse ‚Äì but only if they know all the relevant keyboard shortcuts. With the 2508 release we provide information about available keyboard shortcuts directly where you need them, in the context of the application. By selecting ‚ÄúKeyboard Shortcuts‚Äù in the user menu, a new window appears explaining all the available shortcuts for the application area currently in focus. If you click on a different part of the application, or navigate somewhere else, then the window showing the available shortcuts is updated immediately for the new context.

Figure 23 shows an example for Manage Journal Entries, where the focus is currently on the filter bar. Clicking on the the table results in many more shortcuts being shown, for example for the arrow keys for moving up and down etc., as shown in Figure 24.

Figure 23: In-context documentation of keyboard shortcuts, for the filter bar. Alt Text: A screenshot of the app ‚ÄúManage Journal Entries‚Äù with the focus on the filter bar, with a second window on the right containing Keyboard Shortcuts in two groups, ‚ÄúGlobal Shortcuts‚Äù and ‚ÄúGeneric Keyboard Interactions‚Äù.

Figure 24: In-context documentation of keyboard shortcuts, for the table. Alt Text: A screenshot of the app ‚ÄúManage Journal Entries‚Äù with the focus on the table, with a second window on the right containing Keyboard Shortcuts in two groups, ‚ÄúGlobal Shortcuts‚Äù and ‚ÄúJournal Entries (43,854)‚Äù. The latter contains descriptions for shortcuts for the table, such as the arrow up, down, left, right keys, or using ‚ÄúCmd + D‚Äù to delete.

Automatic Update of SAP Fiori Apps Upon Change of Data in Backend

There are quite a few cases where users would appreciate seeing absolutely up-to-date data in their application, so that the data is automatically updated if changes occur in the backend. These changes could be made by other users, or by automated background processing . An example for the latter is the Traceability Results application, which is now automatically updated if a batch run has created new traceability items.

Note that this only supported by applications built with SAP Fiori elements using OData V4.

Improved performance for scrolling in grid tables

Our engineers have done some magic so that now scrolling is very fast in grid tables, which are the table type typically used for working with large volumes of data.

Why do I call it magic? Well, modern web-based UIs have the UI layer running in the browser, managing direct user interactions, and calling services in the backend to get and update data. However, if you are working with a list of say over 100,000 items, you would have to wait quite a long time when starting the application until all items have been loaded into the browser. Hence we only load a certain number to start with, such as 100. This however means that when a user scrolls beyond the 100 which have been loaded, additional data needs to be fetched from the backend, which slows down scrolling. Now, our engineers have found a way to minimize this effect to almost zero, so that you have fast scrolling all the time ‚Äì magic!

Figure 25: Performance improvement for scrolling in grid tables. Alt Text: a short video showing scrolling through a grid table.

Whenever the threshold is reached and more data needs to be loaded, there is a very short delay, with the progress indicator being shown for a few milliseconds, as you can see in Figure 25. In most cases, this is completely negligible. Nevertheless, we do also provide customers the option to change the number of entries loaded by default when the application is started. This is useful if a customer knows that, for a certain application, the number of entries will not exceed 2.000 for example. Then they can set the threshold to 2.000, which means that the application will take a little bit longer to load first time around, but then scrolling will be instantaneous for all the data. Figure 26 shows the UI for doing this, as part of UI adaptation. The ‚ÄúThreshold‚Äù determines the maximum number of entries loaded when the application is started, the ‚ÄúScroll Threshold‚Äù determines the maximum number that are loaded during scrolling if new entries need to be fetched.

Figure 26: UI adaptation to determine the threshold determining the maximum number of entries loaded in a table when an application is started. Alt Text: A screenshot with a pop-over ‚ÄúConfigure Table‚Äù with two new fields ‚ÄúThreshold‚Äù, being edited with the value 3000, and ‚ÄúScroll Threshold‚Äù, containing the value 300.

Table Grouping and/or ‚ÄúShow more per row‚Äù State can be Shared

If a user personalizes a table by grouping entries by one of the fields, such as the date, this grouping is persisted when sharing the link with a colleague: when the colleague opens the application with the link, they see the same grouping applied.

Similarly, if ‚Äúshow more per row‚Äù was selected by the user before sharing the link, the recipient will also see more information per row upon opening the application via the link. This information is also stored when saving a view of a table.

Sort or Group Tables by ID or Description

SAP Fiori apps display the ID and the description in the same column within a table, which provides a better experience than having them in two separate columns.

Now, we offer users a choice when sorting or grouping the table by a column which contains both ID and description: they can choose to do this by ID or by description. As you can see in Figure 27, this selection is very intuitive. The example shows what it looks like when sorting by Company Code. At the bottom of the table you see an entry ‚Äú1710 (BestRun US)‚Äù, where the Company Code (the ID) is 1710 and the Company Name (the Description) is ‚ÄúBestRun US‚Äù. In the popover ‚ÄúSort By‚Äù section, the row of icons next to Company Code and Company Name indicate that currently no sorting is active, with the option to sort either bei Code or by Name ascending or descending.

Figure 27: Sort or group tables by ID (in this case Company Code) or by Description (Company Name) when both are displayed together in one column . Alt Text: A screenshot of part of the Manage Journal Entries app, with a list of journal entries and a pop-over ‚ÄúColumn Settings‚Äù with two sections ‚ÄúSort By‚Äù and ‚ÄúGroup By‚Äù. The ‚ÄúSort By‚Äù section has two lines, ‚ÄúCompany Code‚Äù and ‚ÄúCompany Name‚Äù, and offers three buttons with icons for each of these, representing ‚Äúno sorting‚Äù, ‚Äúascending‚Äù, ‚Äúdescending‚Äù.

Hiding Description Fields in List of Fields in Table Settings

For tables as above where ID and description are displayed in one column, technically, the ID and description are stored in two different fields. Until now, when users personalize the table, both the ID and the description were listed in the list of columns, which confused some users.

Now, we have addressed this by providing the option to hide the descriptions (see Figure 28), and hence simplifying personalization. This option is on by default, i.e. the description fields are automatically hidden now.

Figure 28: Description fields can be hidden from the list of fields shown when personalizing tables. Alt Text: A screenshot with a pop-over ‚ÄúView Settings‚Äù containing tabs ‚ÄúColumns‚Äù, ‚ÄúSort‚Äù, ‚ÄúFilter‚Äù, and a pop-over ‚ÄúFilters‚Äù with two options ‚ÄúHide descriptions‚Äù (selected) and ‚ÄúHide Unselected‚Äù (deselected) . ‚ÄúColumns‚Äù is selected and shows a list of columns with check marks. The third entry is ‚ÄúCompany Code‚Äù, followed by ‚ÄúCreated On‚Äù ‚Äì i.e. the description column ‚ÄúCompany Name‚Äù is not listed next to the ‚ÄúCompany Code‚Äù.

These are the highlights of our changes in details. For the full list of what‚Äôs new since the FPS00 shipment of the 2023 release, have a look at the What‚Äôs New Viewer:

  • What‚Äôs New for SAP Fiori launchpad for SAP S/4HANA and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition.

 

UI adaptation improvements for key users

We have made significant enhancements to UI Adaptation for key users with the 2025 release. The ‚ÄúAdapt UI‚Äù option which key users see in their user menu shows you what you can change in the app, in a very intuitive way. And you can change and adapt far more than in the past. See below for some highlights.

Also good to know: the Adapt UI menu entry is also available when using a Classic app (SAP GUI for HTML) from within the SAP Fiori launchpad. It will bring up the Adapt UI app for Screen Personas F5740 Adapt UI for Classic Applications with Screen Personas, which allows key users to adapt the layout of these classic UIs.

Key Users Can Rearrange ID and Description Within a Field or Column

SAP applications come with a standard arrangement of ID and description within a field or a column, based on user research. We have found that for financial users, it is usually best to have the ID first and the description in brackets: Company Code (Company Description), for example ‚Äú1710 (BestRun US)‚Äù as shown in Figure 27. For users in sales and logistics, it is usually best to have the name first and the ID in brackets: for example Customer Name (Customer ID), for example ‚ÄúUS Specialty Cycles 5 (USCU_S05)‚Äù as shown in Figure 2.

Now, key users can use UI adaptation to rearrange the order for a given application. Doing this change applies then to all occurrences of the field in the application, i.e. the filter bar, the table or in a form on an object page.

Far More Options for Key Users to Adapt UIs

Key users can now make far more significant changes to UIs than before. For example, they can add a button to clear all filter values in the filter bar, remove buttons such as the ‚ÄúExport to Excel‚Äù, and much more. Figure 29 shows the options for configuring a table for example.

Figure 29: Many more options for Key Users to adapt UIs. Alt Text: UI Adaptation is shown switched on for the application Manage Bank Hierarchies, with a popover called ‚ÄúConfigure Table‚Äù filling half the screen, and showing 12 options such as ‚ÄúEnable Table Export‚Äù, ‚ÄúFrozen Column Count‚Äù with a field for entering the number, ‚ÄúSorting‚Äù, ‚ÄúColumns‚Äù etc.

 

Design and Technology News

For a comprehensive overview of the recent design and technology news, have a look at my blog posts from Q1 and Q3 2025. These are also relevant for the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition and SAP S/4HANA 2025 release, since the design and technology are already available in the cloud:

  • SAP User Experience Q1/2025 Update ‚Äì Part 7: UI Design and Technology for Web and Mobile
  • SAP UX Q3/2025 Update ‚Äì Part 7: UI Design and Technology for Web and Mobile
    Note though that the SAP Build Extensibility Wizard presented there is currently only integrated with for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.

We are progressing at such a pace, that I have some additional news to share with you, not covered by the above posts. In addition, I would like to explicitly mention some particular highlights here from the above posts too.

Regarding extensibility: do have a look at the new SAP Extensibility Explorer.

SAP Design System Portal and UI Kits ‚Äì now with AI Components

We recently introduced the new SAP Design System portal that brings together the product design guidelines SAP Fiori for web, SAP Fiori for iOS, and SAP Fiori for Android, as well as to the new digital design system guidelines. With its enhanced usability, simplified versioning and improved performance, designers (and developers!) get a better user experience compared with the previous SAP Fiori design guidelines.

The new UI Kits available for designers in Figma make it easy for designers to design accessible UIs at enterprise scale, for web applications, mobile iOS and Android applications as well as wearables. The UI Kits provide reusable components for web and mobile, along with web floorplans, which give you what you need out-of-the-box.

We have just released SAP Web UI Kit v8.0 which includes a full set of AI components: AI Button, AI Menu Button, AI Split Menu Button, AI Prompt Input, AI Input, AI Text Area, and AI Rich Text Editor.

Figure 30: The SAP Design System portal start page (on the left), and SAP‚Äôs UI Kits for designers in Figma (on the right). Alt Text: Two screenshots. The portal page shows four main sections SAP Fiori for Web, ‚Ä¶ for Android, ‚Ä¶ for iOS, and SAP Digital Design System, each followed by links to UI elements, Figma kits, and overviews. The UI Kits show 8 cards, SAP Fiori for Android, Web, iOS, watchOS, Wear OS, Performance, Accessibility and SAP S/4HANA.

Find out more here:

  • New SAP Design System Portal for SAP Fiori Design Guidelines, and New UI Kits for Designers.

SAP Fiori Development Portal

I‚Äôm also happy to inform you about the new SAP Fiori development portal, introduced a few weeks ago. It is designed to help developers maximize the benefits of SAP Fiori elements for OData V4, which is more than just a UI framework: it‚Äôs a metadata-driven approach that leverages the SAP Design System as its guiding principle, incorporating the most relevant design system options for typical business tasks.

Figure 31: The SAP Fiori development portal. Alt text: A screenshot showing the Introduction page. On the left a menu has entries Using the Portal, Building Blocks, Global Patterns, Floorplans, SAP Fiori Tools. The Introduction page has a full width card ‚ÄúBuilding Blocks‚Äù at the top, with a description and tiles representing various building blocks. Below that ‚ÄúChoose Your Option‚Äù heading above two side-by-side cards for ‚ÄúFloorplans‚Äù and ‚ÄúCustomer Layout‚Äù, each with an image and description, and a ‚ÄúLearn More‚Äù button.

The SAP Fiori development portal puts building blocks front and center. These building blocks - such as tables, forms, filter bars, and charts - are orchestrated by SAP Fiori elements and form the basis of every OData V4 application. They provide standardized layouts and interaction patterns, ensuring UI consistency and boosting developer productivity. The great advantage of using building blocks is that you can use them to create a customer layout and yet still benefit from the advantages of the metadata driven approach: low code, built in enterprise-grade capabilities such as multi-language support, accessibility, security and performance, and design system consistency.

Find out more in this six-part series of blog posts, here is the first one, which contains links to the others:

  • Introducing the SAP Fiori Development Portal: Your Gateway to Rapid SAP Fiori App Creation (1 of 6).

Using AI to Develop UIs

The above posts from Q1/2025 and Q3/2025 introduced a number of powerful ways to accelerate UI development by using AI, such as:

  • Creating SAP Fiori elements apps from a sketch (in the Q1 post), now integrated in SAP Build Code and Joule (Q3 post)
  • Joule for SAPUI5 freestyle development (Q1 post)
  • AI-assisted auto-fix of coding errors with UI5 linter (Q3 post)

Recently, we have gone even further and introduced MCP servers for freestyle SAPUI5 development as well as for developing with SAP Fiori elements and the associated building blocks. These open-source Model Context Protocol (MCP) servers provide AI agents with comprehensive UI5 and SAP Fiori elements knowledge, including best practices and project-aware context information, and thus provide developers with valuable support. Figure 32 shows examples. 

Figure 32: Examples of the UI5 MCP Server (on the left) and the MCP Server for SAP Fiori (on the right) in action. Alt Text: both images show screenshots of a CLINE console view with a task entered as text at the top, followed by a list of steps which the system proposes to do to solve the task.

 Read about these new MCP servers in these blog posts:

  • UI5 MCP Server.
  • MCP Server for SAP Fiori.

Accessibility taken to the next level: WCAG 2.2 support

Accessibility is key to using SAP's business solutions. Adopting the latest standards gives applications a true cutting edge, ensuring that solutions are inclusive and meet the diverse needs of users globally. When creating apps with SAP Build and SAPUI5, developers can leverage the latest Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG) 2.2.

For example, two of the key new requirements in the 2.2 version are:

  • The minimum target size of an interactive element now needs to be 24x24 px, so that users don‚Äôt accidentally activate a neighbouring element.
  • Each operation that can be performed by dragging can also be performed alternatively without dragging ‚Äì so that people who cannot use a mouse to drag can still use the UI.

See more details:

  • SAPUI5 is Leading the Way in Accessibility with WCAG 2.2 

Blue Crystal and Belize Themes No Longer Available in the Web

As announced in April (Upcoming Removal of SAP Fiori Themes Belize and Blue Crystal), the visual themes Blue Crystal and Belize have been removed from our web UI technology with the 2025 release of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition and SAP S/4HANA.

 After upgrading, existing usages of Belize or Blue Crystal will be automatically redirected to the Horizon theme.

If you have created your own custom theme based on Belize or Blue Crystal using the UI theme designer, you will need to migrate this to an available theme. Our strong recommendation is to base the new version on the Horizon theme.

For more information about the web UI technologies affected, and how to migrate custom themes, have a look at this blog post:

  • Announcement: Removal of Belize theme of SAP Fiori.

Note that SAP GUI for Windows continues to support older themes, including Blue Crystal and Belize.

 

Final words

Come join us at TechEd 2025, November 4 - 6, either virtually or in Berlin, or at one of the TechEd On The Road events in Louisville (USA), Bangalore (India) and Sydney (Australia), to find out more about our latest user experience innovations. I myself will be in Berlin and Bangalore, so feel free to approach me after my talks if you have any specific questions. I‚Äôm looking forward to meeting some of you!

 This blog posts gives an overview of all the UX related sessions at all four events:

  • Exciting UX talks at TechEd ‚Äì Virtual, or meet us in Berlin and On The Road (USA, India, Australia).

 Please continue using the community to share your learnings and best practices, either by posting articles yourselves or via comments on this post. You can also follow me in the community if you want to be notified about further similar updates from me.

entry.title: On-Premise Business AI Infrastructure for Small and Medium Enterprises Using NVIDIA DGX Spark
entry.content:
Disclaimer: this article is written without Generative AI, even for the proof reading üòä Enjoy the article written by human that is not common nowadays

Why Business AI?

That is what we always must start with. The business case should go first, for sure, and then we should evaluate possible deployment options, costs and security.

Statistics says that 95% of Generative AI implementations failed and that really scares the market in SAP enterprise software domain as well.

But let‚Äôs be honest, we are trying to sell Business AI anywhere as technology, forgetting about the customers, their uniqueness and their current pain points.

At Skybuffer starting from February 2025 (during the last 9 months) we have talked to more than 250 customers of different sizes presenting them Business AI technologies and discussing their use cases, or better to say helping them to find how Business AI can help their employees and partners to automate company‚Äôs workflows.

There are three main groups of use cases, as we see it now:

  • Direct interaction with SAP backend system via corporate messengers that brings simplicity and mobility at the same time. In many cases Creating or Updating data in SAP from mobile phones or via Teams brings real value.
  • Converting any unstructured data to knowledge, like SharePoint sources, attachments in SAP, support tickets. Mixing those things together, in different document original languages create real value for employees providing them access to the data that is hidden in most of the organizations.
  • Capacity heavy activities delivered by AI agents, especially helpful with emails data analysis, where the main data is always in attachments. Sometimes it requires to utilize OCR extracting data from scanned PDFs in those scenarios. Some excellent examples are processing vendors emails and posting invoice or service entry sheets into SAP or receiving emails from customers converting their external purchasing data to sales orders.

That is why SAP customers with any SAP backend system, either SAP ECC or S/4HANA, can implement Business AI today. I am not saying that it covers the entire Business AI implementation benefits, however, that is what we are focusing on now and helping SAP customers to allocate the benefits of using the technology.

Costs

In our opinion, Business AI is close to being the tool that must be deployed inside IT infrastructure, but a technology that is to being considered only if it returns the investment. Think about the indirect impact of missing Business AI in your business landscape. For example, consider the costs of hiring new staff because your employees are moving to other companies that utilize modern technologies. Why should they move? Obvious, because of the same reason we are all talking about Generative AI ‚Äì to stay competitive on the market.

However, costs of AI must be assessed carefully, because in most of the architecture approaches Business AI is a consumption-based solution. Risky, isn‚Äôt it? Of course! Consumption is hard to estimate, and it is also hard to avoid picks, so budgets of Business AI productive usage might be unacceptably high compared to the potential savings the technology brings. That is why we built Skybuffer AI as a solution with the double deployment options:

  • On premise, there is a clear and 100% predictable TCO.
  • On SAP BTP, this is a great option for CPEA contracts, for example, because in this case Business AI consumes the credits that are already paid, and we avoid extra costs for the infrastructure.

Why is DGX Spark in the article name?

Well, DGX Spark here is not because it is a buzz word now, for sure. That is because DGX Spark provides an excellent opportunity for small and medium enterprises to bring 15x15x12 cm GPU-unit to support their Business AI operations for a very compatible price. Actually, it allows us to keep both compute-unit and GPU-unit in the network avoiding data leakage and consumption-based costs. Excellent? Of course!

Here is how we use it deploying Skybuffer AI on premise:

Figure 01. Skybuffer AI deployment with GPU-unit served by DGX Spark

Criticism?

Yes, even writing this article I am already hearing the criticism üòä Guessing the comments like, ‚Äúthat is not for productive environment‚Äù, ‚ÄúDGX Spark tokens generation too low to serve even Small businesses‚Äù and many other sharp negatives. But let‚Äôs move back to the beginning of the article and understand the reason why I‚Äôve spent so much time talking about use cases first. Yes, now it is obvious that many mentioned use cases can be addressed by DGX Spark working as GPU-unit. Example? Easy!

Example #1: Vendor emails processing with data posting into SAP backend and saving originals (files) into the DMS (like SharePoint, Join, Google or whatever DMS is in use).

In the architecture mentioned above, Skybuffer AI allows almost out of the box creation of an AI Agent that will check, for example, Account Payable mailbox, read emails, analyze attachments, move them to DMS and create financial postings in SAP backend saving links to the attachments in DMS (either external or internal SAP DMS) on the SAP financial document level. In scenario, if we schedule the agent carefully, it can work in the almost synchronous 24/7 mode.

In case we schedule the Vendor Emails processing AI Agent with the limit to process just one vendor email in the minute, we will avoid pick system loads, and in this case, we can keep AI agent active 24/7. In such deployment it will be able to process 1 440 emails and create postings in SAP a day, that gives us 43 200 a month and amazing number of 518 400 documents a year!! All powered by one DGX Spark GPU-unit keeping the data on premise and avoiding cloud consumption.

That is what we call a proper deployment of Business AI. And Small and Medium businesses do not usually have such big number of documents from vendors, even the Cirque du Soleil does not have according to the latest SAP news post üòä What we usually do, we add extra Business AI scenarios to be processed by the same Skybuffer AI deployment.

Example #2: Automation of SAP user management services

Small and Medium businesses do use password-based login to SAP backend, so users keep locking themselves or forgetting their passwords. Do we need a powerful GPU-unit with the full size LLM to automate this? No, for sure. We can add those business scenarios to the AI Agent that is processing Vendor Emails üòä

Example #3: Bank data reconciliation

The same setup can be used to assist financial department to match bank transactions to the billing documents in SAP and post accruals for the cases that could not be reconciled, for example, those that miss billing data in SAP that is not created just because someone has forgotten to enter it or integration interfaces have data processing issues. DGX Spark GPU-unit provides particularly good enough capacity here as well.

Those are just a few examples that wind away the skepticism about the utilization of DGX Spark in productive environment.

Is it safe to invest in the on-premise Business AI setup?

If you need full control over costs and data security, the answer is yes. And we think that the answer is yes in general, because Skybuffer AI dual deployment capabilities gives companies the guarantee that on premise Business AI investment can follow their potential future cloud strategy. I am writing and hearing again ‚Äúwhat is this crazy man talking about! On premise investment can follow cloud strategies?? That is a paradox!‚Äù. And again, the answer is No, of course there is no paradox! If we look at the deployment of Skybuffer AI with integration with SAP Joule:

 Figure 02: Skybuffer AI deployment in SAP BTP with integration with SAP Joule

That is what we call real flexibility!

Sounds like a Gap Closing Solution?

Yes, that is the conclusion we have. There no hard choice anymore to run Business AI on premise or on SAP BTP, no prerequisites to start using Business AI, because the deployment in this article works with SAP ECC (down to 7.01 and even below), SAP S/4HANA on premise or SAP S/4HANA in private cloud. The only question must be asked, when we are talking about Business AI, is about the scenario the company should start with? You‚Äôve seen in our examples that Business AI deployments might bring benefits working in the scenarios that are independent from the historical data you have in your SAP backend and the historical data quality (sometimes it is called data silos), or scenarios that are independent from the version of your system and the point in time of your current digital journey. No need to wait for the upgrades, migrations, or other activities that sound like an act of catching a tail üòä. Just allocate some budget for Business AI deployment, for example, on-premise deployment on DGX Spark that is very affordable, and get the positive feedback from your employees or business partners and enjoy your business workflows simplifications.

entry.title: Install custom functions in COHV (3/3)
entry.content:
Introduction

The previous two episodes have demonstrated how to create and register a custom mass processing function code in COHV as well as have provided an outline of the actual implementation of the mass processing. However, the implementation has not done anything useful, yet.

Now, it is the time to add some meat to the implementation and dive into more advanced topics like test mode, function parametrization and order updates.

 

Test mode

Let us start with test mode. Typically, SAP standard mass processing functions provide a test mode option that runs all data processing without actually saving any changes or updates. That is particularly useful if you want to test a mass processing run without committing the updates.
Figure 1 Test mode on

Figure 2 Test mode off

The implementation of the mass processing function does not need to explicitly handle test mode operation, i.e. either to rollback or commit changes. That is done by COHV backbone. Make sure to test thoroughly if the test mode is used to make sure that the custom mass processing function is compatible with the test mode handling in COHV. If you are not sure, the rule of thumb is not to use the test mode.

 

Passing parameters to the mass processing function

Mass processing functions can be supplied with additional parameters. That is often used in SAP standard functions, and it can be enabled for custom ones.

First, additional parameters need to be added to the transparent table and the dialog structure that have been created in the episode 2. Make sure to add the same fields of the same type to the table and to the structure.
Figure 3 The transparent table with a parameter

Figure 4 The dialog structure with a parameter

Once that is done, the parameter will appear in COHV.
Figure 6 The function's parameter in COHV

 

Mass processing logic implementation

Now, let‚Äôs implement the mass processing logic to update production orders. My goal is to change production orders quantity by the value passed with the function parameter. The implementation goes into Z_CO_WORK999_EXEX_SINGLE function. Refer to the previous episode for the details of the function creation.
Figure 7 A snippet of the mass processing logic implementation

Here is the entire implementation of the custom mass processing logic, which consists of the following steps:

  1. Get a production order number from LS_COWBPAR-OBJNR
  2. Read the order‚Äôs header details with the BAPI_PRODORD_GET_DETAIL function
  3. Modify the order quantity by the value of the function parameter. It is available in the LS_COWBPAR-QTYCHANGE field
  4. Update the order with the BAPI_PRODORD_CHANGE function
*** BEGIN custom mass processing logic
   DATA:
     prodord    TYPE cowrk_s_prodord_mask,
     return     TYPE bapiret2,
     headers    TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF bapi_order_header1,
     orderdata  TYPE bapi_pp_order_change,
     orderdatax TYPE bapi_pp_order_changex,
     dummy      TYPE string.
 
  prodord = ls_cowbpar-objnr.
 
  CALL FUNCTION 'BAPI_PRODORD_GET_DETAIL'
     EXPORTING
       number        = prodord-aufnr
       order_objects = VALUE bapi_pp_order_objects( header = abap_true )
     TABLES
       header        = headers.
 
  READ TABLE headers INDEX 1 ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(<header>).
   orderdata-quantity = <header>-target_quantity + ls_cowbpar-qtychange.
   orderdatax-quantity = abap_true.
 
  CLEAR return.
 
  CALL FUNCTION 'BAPI_PRODORD_CHANGE'
     EXPORTING
       number     = prodord-aufnr
       orderdata  = orderdata
       orderdatax = orderdatax
     IMPORTING
       return     = return.
 
  IF return IS INITIAL.
     MESSAGE s100(co) WITH prodord-aufnr INTO dummy.
   ELSE.
     MESSAGE ID return-id TYPE return-type NUMBER return-number
     WITH return-message_v1 return-message_v2 return-message_v3 return-message_v4
     INTO dummy.
   ENDIF.
 
  ls_context-aufnr = ls_exec_obj-aufnr.
   CALL FUNCTION 'CO_APPLLOG_WRITE_SYMSG'
     EXPORTING
       i_loghandle           = ls_appllog-log_handle
       i_syst                = syst
       is_context            = ls_context
     EXCEPTIONS
       application_log_error = 1
       OTHERS                = 2.
 *** END custom mass processing logic

entry.title: üöÄ What‚Äôs New in Floorplan Manager (FPM) for Web Dynpro ABAP in SAP S/4HANA 2025
entry.content:
Dear SAP Community,

When it comes to the design of web-based user interfaces, SAP truly has a rich history. A great example is the EPM Purchase Order Demo (FPM/WDA application S_EPM_FPM_PO) (see Figure 1):

Figure 1: Application S_EPM_FPM_PO ‚Äì Design evolution over the years

Design themes such as Tradeshow, Corbusier, Blue Crystal, Belize, or Quartz are well known to many developers. But the journey doesn‚Äôt end there ‚Äî it continues toward new Horizons and compliance with the WCAG 2.2 Accessibility Standard.

In the latest releases, several new features have been added to the Floorplan Manager (FPM) / Web Dynpro ABAP framework, driven by customer feedback, SAP design standards, and general product evolution. With the ABAP Platform 2025 and SAP S/4HANA 2025 (on-premise, private cloud, and public cloud editions), we are delivering several enhancements that can be activated easily ‚Äî either automatically through delivery or manually with minimal configuration or coding effort.

üß≠ Page Header UIBBs & Object Page Mode

In one of my previous blogs on S/4HANA 2023, üëâ Team FPM: How to Render an FPM Overview Page to Look Like a SAP Fiori Object Page, I introduced the Object Page Mode for the Overview Page (OVP) floorplan.

This mode allows you to render an FPM Overview Page application like a Fiori Object Page. Combined with a Page Header UIBB, you get a dynamic object header that automatically expands and collapses while scrolling. You can also pin the header to keep it fixed. You can easily try this out in the Search Page of the EPM Purchase Order Demo (see Figure 2).

Figure 2: S_EPM_FPM_PO with Page Header, Pin and List Item Navigation

The new List-Item Navigation lets users navigate to a Purchase Order‚Äôs detail page in a Fiori-compliant way. On the detail page, the Object Page Mode provides faster and more precise scrolling to specific screen areas (sections or UIBBs) using the Navigation Bar (see Figure 3).

Figure 3: Purchase Order Detail Page with Anchor Bar

Configuration

  • Object Page Mode is activated in the General Settings as a Floorplan Mode (see Figure 4).
  • To use a dynamic object header, define a Page Header Area in the layout and add Page Header UIBBs.

Figure 4: Object Page Mode setting in FLUID for OVP Floorplan S_EPM_UX_PO_OVP

In the List or Tree UIBB, a List-Item Navigation corresponds to rendering a Link-To-Action column differently. You can achieve this by checking Render as Navigation Column in the column configuration (see Figure 5).

Figure 5: Setting ‚ÄúPurchase Order ID‚Äù as Navigation Column in FLUID for List UIBB EPM_PO_OVP_SEARCH_LIST_CFG

Additional Remarks

Some OVP floorplan features may behave differently in Object Page Mode. This can affect:

  • Header rendering
  • UIBB Selector and Page Master splitter control
  • Section and UIBB stacking
  • Personalization and panel behavior

However, Power User Modes allow overriding some restrictions ‚Äî such as expanding and collapsing panels, or rearranging the layout by using the personalization dialog.

üß© CSS Grid Layout & WCAG 2.2 Compliance

Another major improvement is the WCAG 2.2-compliant rendering of forms. We‚Äôve significantly enhanced the responsiveness of the Form/Repeater UIBB (GL2) by adopting a CSS Grid Layout.

This ensures that forms remain usable and readable ‚Äî even at screen widths as low as 320px (mobile phone format) ‚Äî without horizontal scrolling (see Figure 6).

 Figure 6: ‚ÄúPurchase Order Details‚Äù form in different screen sizes

In the configuration editor (FLUID), you can enable the CSS Grid layout at General Settings ‚Üí Layout Design Type ‚Üí Responsive (see Figure 7).

Figure 7: FLUID configuration for Form UIBB EPM_PO_OVP_HEADER_FORM_CFG

üí¨Message Toasts & Invisible Alerts

In this context, it‚Äôs worth mentioning the Message Toast and Invisible Alert features, which enhance both usability and accessibility. A Message Toast is a small, non-disruptive popup for success messages that disappears automatically after a few seconds (see Figure 8). The  IF_FPM_MESSAGE_MANAGER ABAP interface now provides the REPORT_MESSAGE_TOAST method for this purpose. You can also enable a Toast Mode globally with the SET_TOAST_MODE( IV_TOAST_MODE = GC_TOAST_MODE-ENABLED ) method,  ensuring that messages of severity Success (S) are displayed as toasts by default (see also SAP Help Portal).

Figure 8: ‚ÄúData Saved‚Äù Toast in S_EPM_FPM_PO

An Invisible Alert, on the other hand, is used to inform screen reader users about content changes that are visible but not triggered by them ‚Äî ensuring WCAG 2.2 compliance. Use the REPORT_INVISIBLE_ALERT method from the IF_FPM_MESSAGE_MANAGER interface for this purpose.

üîôFLP Back Navigation

Finally, let us introduce Back Navigation in the SAP Fiori Launchpad (FLP).

You can now configure where the FLP back button should navigate to. By default, it goes back to the previous application, but often it‚Äôs more useful to return to the previous page within the same application. For example, when navigating from a main page to an edit page, you likely want the back button to return to the main page of the same object. Further details are available in SAP Help Portal.

‚úÖSummary

With SAP S/4HANA 2025, the Floorplan Manager for Web Dynpro ABAP continues its evolution toward:

  • A Fiori-consistent Object Page experience
  • Improved accessibility (WCAG 2.2)
  • More responsive layouts
  • Enhanced user feedback mechanisms (message toasts, invisible alerts)
  • Smarter navigation handling in the Fiori Launchpad

These innovations make it easier than ever for FPM-based applications to deliver a modern, accessible, and consistent user experience ‚Äî across all S/4HANA deployment options.

Thank you for reading ‚Äî and see you next time! üòä

entry.title: Secure By Default: SAP S/4HANA 2025 ‚Äì The Security Journey Continues
entry.content:
What began as a bold initiative to strengthen the default security posture of SAP S/4HANA has, over the years, evolved into a core principle of the product. While the journey from concept to execution took time, we‚Äôve now reached a point where Secure By Default is not just an aspiration - it‚Äôs a continuously expanding reality. With each release, more robust security settings are seamlessly integrated, helping customers benefit from enhanced protection without additional effort.

With the release of SAP S/4HANA 2025, also named SAP Cloud ERP Private 2025,  another step was taken by SAP S/4HANA supported by ABAP Platform to cover some additional topics for new installations, conversions, and system copies.

Identical to the former years, Secure By Default settings are applied for

    • SAP S/4HANA 2025 / SAP Cloud ERP Private 2025
    • All SAP products based on S/4HANA Foundation 2025

List of new Secure By Default Settings

In new installations, system copies, and conversions the following security relevant settings and configurations are applied automatically:

    • Add support for TLS1.3 for web-based interfaces of SAP S/4HANA in addition to TLS1.2
    • Adjust the security log of ICM to make it machine-readable for easier integration into SIEM solutions
    • Disable support for SAP logon tickets while still accepting SAP Assertion Tickets
    • Configure a Report-only Content Security Policy (CSP) for faster introduction of a Content Security Policy as second level of defence for S/4HANA
    • Disable the outdated ICM content scan interface as dedicated checks have been introduced in browser-based applications against Cross Site Scripting (XSS) and input validation.

Additional Information

As with SAP S/4HANA 1909, SAP S/4HANA 2020, SAP S/4HANA 2021, SAP S/4HANA 2023 customers will receive the security settings automatically with new installations, system copies and conversions. An opt-out is possible for the security relevant profile parameters but not recommended from SAP side. More details can be found in SAP Note 2926224.

As Secure By Default settings cannot and will not cover all aspects of security settings in S/4HANA systems, we highly recommend customers to perform additional reviews and improvements of their security settings. Good sources are the SAP security whitepapers. Secure by Default settings provide a good starting point, but there are additional security settings and configurations which are either customer specific, cannot be shipped as default or need to be applied on a regular basis (e.g., security patching).

    • Use the SAP-provided tools and services, such as Early Watch Alert, Configuration Validation and System Recommendations in order to display missing security patches. These inform you about gaps in a cost-efficient way.
    • Always introduce disruptive security settings with good timing. Conversion projects and new installations are opportunities to increase security. As a benefit, security testing can be included as part of the testing activities planned within the project. This leverages synergies in the area that has proven to be particularly costly.

Please refer to these blog posts for older SAP S/4HANA releases

    • For SAP S/4HANA 2023 ‚Äì Secure By Default, please also refer to this blog https://blogs.sap.com/2023/10/18/another-chapter-of-secure-by-default-for-sap-s-4hana-2023/
    • For SAP S/4HANA 2022 ‚Äì Secure By Default, please also refer to this blog https://blogs.sap.com/2022/11/03/secure-by-default-returns-with-sap-s-4hana-2022
    • For SAP S/4HANA 2021 ‚Äì Secure By Default, please also refer to this blog The story resumes ‚Äì Secure By Default for SAP S/4HANA 2021
    • For SAP S/4HANA 2020 ‚Äì Secure By Default, please also refer to this blog Secure By Default for SAP S/4HANA 2020
    • For SAP S/4HANA 1909 ‚Äì Secure By Default, please also refer to this blog Secure By Default: Ways To Harden Your Systems At (Almost) No Cost

Complete List of all SAP S/4HANA Secure By Default Settings

Below you can find a complete list of all Secure By Default settings that are included in SAP S/4HANA 2025. Bold entries were added with SAP S/4HANA 2025:

    • Security relevant profile parameters are set to secure values which increases security in areas such as:
        • Mandatory SSL Protection of session logon tickets (part of S/4HANA 2022)
        • Disable support for SAP logon tickets while still accepting SAP Assertion Tickets (part of S/4HANA 2025)
        • Protect the RFC gateway against unauthorized RFC call forwarding (part of S/4HANA 2022)
        • Strong password policies and password hashes (part of S/4HANA 2020)
        • Protection of internal system communication (part of S/4HANA 2020)
        • Strengthened authorizations system (part of S/4HANA 1909)
        • Enhanced RFC interface protection (part of S/4HANA 1909)
        • Enforce TLS1.2-only for web-based interfaces of SAP S/4HANA covering SAP Internet Communication Manager (ICM), SAP Start Service, SAP Host Agent (part of S/4HANA 2022)
        • Add support for TLS1.3 for web-based interfaces of SAP S/4HANA in addition to TLS1.2 (part of S/4HANA 2025)
        • Disable the old insecure tickets for trusted / trusting communication (part of S/4HANA 2023)
        • Disable the outdated ICM content scan interface as dedicated checks have been introduced in the browser-based applications against Cross Site Scripting (XSS) and input validation (part of S/4HANA 2025)
    • Security relevant configurations and customizing are set to secure values
        • Prevent usage of non-reference user as reference user (part of S/4HANA 2022)
        • 3 parameters were changed to secure defaults in the Transport Management (part of S/4HANA 2021)
        • Web protection is increased by activation of the UCON HTTP allowlist (part of S/4HANA 2021)
        • Start authorizations for WebDynpro were enabled for an improved security for Webdynpro applications (part of S/4HANA 2021)
        • All available scenarios of the Switchable Authorization Framework (SACF) are activated which adds additional functional authorization checks for technical function modules (part of S/4HANA 2020)
        • All available scenarios of the Generic Application Access Rules (SLDW) were activated as defined by SAP development (part of S/4HANA 2021)
        • Prevent the assignment of users to roles as part of transports to avoid that users get authorizations in higher tiers while importing transports (part of S/4HANA 2023)
    • Security relevant logging was enabled to support traceability and security monitoring
        • Performance, usability and analysis optimized log of RFC and SICF usage to support deactivation of unused RFC function modules and SICF services (part of S/4HANA 2022 and S/4HANA 2023)
        • Security Audit Log is activated what allows customers to trace critical activities in the system (part of S/4HANA 1909)
        • Activation of table logging for business-critical tables (part of S/4HANA 2021)
        • HTTP server and HTTP client log of the SAP Internet Communication Manager is enabled (part of S/4HANA 1909)
        • Granular logging of Secure By Default activations in application log for easier debugging in conversions (part of S/4HANA 2023)
        • Adjust the security log of ICM to make it machine-readable for easier integration into SIEM solutions (part of S/4HANA 2025)
        • Configure a Report-only Content Security Policy (CSP) for faster introduction of a Content Security Policy as second level of defence for S/4HANA (part of S/4HANA 2025)
    • HANA for S/4HANA relevant configurations were enabled to improve traceability and encryption
        • SAP HANA Audit Log is switched on for HANAs running SAP S/4HANA. This enables traceability of activities on SAP HANA database level (part of S/4HANA 2021)
        • Leverage the automated activation of HANA Data at Rest Encryption Features as part of HANA2 SP07 installations to ensure that business data cannot be accessed on file system level (part of S/4HANA 2023)
    • Values of additional security relevant profile parameters were changed in the kernel default

entry.title: Supply Protection and Other Methods in aATP
entry.content:
In advanced Available-to-Promise (aATP), customers have different options to optimize the availability of articles or products. Supply protection (SUP) is one of these methods, which is integrated into other processes in aATP. 
Sometimes it‚Äôs not clear how supply protection works with other methods and how to differentiate to other methods. The methods have a lot in common, like the usage of a characteristics catalog. But there are also differences regarding the use cases, the usage in a process, and there are pros and cons for every method. 

Let‚Äôs look at different aspects of the integration of supply protection into the following processes in aATP: 

  • Product Availability Check (PAC) 
  • Product Allocation (PAL) 
  • Backorder Processing (BOP) 
  • Alternative-Based Confirmation (ABC) 
  • Supply Assignment (aRUN) 

Link:

SAP Help: Integration into other Processes

Supply Protection and Product Availability Check (PAC) 

Planned supply protection is relevant for the product availability check (PAC), which determines whether a demand (for example, from a sales order) can be confirmed. The product availability check compares the request of the sales order with the available stock for the related material. Within this logic, there is also a check if there is supply protection available for the relevant combination of material and planning level. If yes, the system calculates the restricted quantities and reduces the available stock for the sales document. If this reduced quantity is not sufficient to meet the request, the sales document will not be (fully) confirmed for the requested delivery date. Supply protection also reduces the available stock after the replenishment lead time (RLT). However, the availability check is calculated with infinity stock. The restrictions defined by supply protection don‚Äôt have an impact after the RLT.  

Whether supply protection is considered in the product availability check depends on the settings for the scope of the availability check. Only if supply protection is activated in the scope of check for the related checking rule, will PAC consider supply protection. For more information, see ‚ÄØHow to Activate Supply Protection. 

As supply protection is integrated in the basic method of the product availability check, the impact of supply protection when creating a sales document is also shown in the‚ÄØReview Availability Check Result‚ÄØapp, as part of the intermediate results of the check. For more information, see ‚ÄØSupply Protection in Review Availability Check Result. 

The following illustration shows how supply protection reduces the availability by adding virtual demands:

Supply Protection within the Product Availability Check

Supply Protection and Product Allocation (PAL) 

Several use cases can be addressed with product allocation or with supply protection; and sometimes they can even be used in combination. Logically, the product allocation check is performed before the availability is checked. Therefore, PAL can limit the request which is checked in PAC (together with SUP). 

What are the differences between Product Allocation and Supply Protection? 

With the sales product allocation check, it is possible to define an upper limit for a group. A matching demand can‚Äôt get a higher confirmation compared to the limit defined in product allocation. As the sales PAL is checked in advance of the product availability check, the allocation ignores the availability situation. A demand which is limited by PAC can‚Äôt get more quantity, even if there is no shortage. In case of a shortage situation, a demand within the defined allocation can get the quantities if the stock is available, and if the PAL limit isn‚Äôt exceeded. This leads to the issue that another requested quantity can‚Äôt get confirmation although there is a matching PAL quantity. 

Supply Protection and Product Allocation
Supply protection is integrated in the product availability check and considers the availability situation. It adds virtual demands so that the availability is reduced, depending on whether the demand matches a supply protection object or not. If there is a lot of supply compared to the protected quantities, supply protection doesn‚Äôt have an impact on sales. 

Can Supply Protection and Product Allocation be Used as Complementary Methods? 

Yes, with supply protection, minimum quantities can be defined. With this, it can be ensured that even in shortage situations important groups can get some quantities. With product allocation, limits can be defined, which prevent a group from taking too much quantity and not leaving enough for others. 

However, there is a risk of a wrong setup, where product allocation prevents the consumption of quantities protected by supply protection, and vice versa. This is the case when, for example, supply protection with high priority exists for a key customer, and there‚Äôs also a product allocation object matching the demands of this key customer. If the product allocation is already consumed, this customer can‚Äôt order more quantity. In this case, consumption of protected quantities in supply protection isn‚Äôt possible, and other demands are restricted by this. 

Advantages of Supply Protection 
Allows different settings of restrictions, but will not limit demands, if there is enough stock/supply. 

Advantages of Product Allocation 
Can be set up also on more generic levels (not only a specific material-plant combination), which requires less maintenance. 

Link: 

SAP Help: Best Practices for Supply Protection ‚Äì Using Supply Protection and Product Allocation 

Supply Protection and Backorder Processing (BOP) 

With backorder processing, it is possible to recheck orders with specific rules so that orders which have been confirmed may lose their confirmation while others can now get confirmed. With BOP, it‚Äôs possible to reallocate available stock to competing sales orders, allowing customers to prioritize some orders ("winners") over others ("losers"). 

This seems to be close to the idea of supply protection. However, the logic of BOP is to reopen sales documents and change the sequence. A winner is processed first and has a rule to get a better result. A loser will come later and has a rule that the result can be worse. 

Links:  

SAP Help: Backorder Processing (CA-ATP-BOP) 

How does Supply Protection work together with BOP? 

While processing backorders, supply protection is checked as well. The consumption of protected quantities in supply protection will get removed temporarily, and the orders which are processed first are also checked against supply protection. The result will be different, but it considers the restrictions of supply protection. 

Naturally, it wouldn‚Äôt make sense to set up protection groups with high priority for demands which should be ‚Äúlosers‚Äù, according to the defined logic for BOP. 

Supply Protection and Alternative Base Confirmation (ABC) 

With ABC, it is possible to define alternative options for supply by exchanging a product and/or a plant. Depending on the rules for ABC, a demand for product A could be replaced by product B, which is not the same but treated as a good substitute. 

From the perspective of supply protection, this is always a new, independent check. The reason is quite simple: product and plant are keys for supply protection. If a product is exchanged by another product, the check for supply protection will search for matches and calculate restrictions for a different material-plant-combination. 

In this case, there won‚Äôt be a consumption for the originally matching supply protection object. For the second check, consumption might be written. 

Link: 

SAP Help: Alternative Base Confirmation (CA-ATP-ABC) 

Supply Protection and Supply Assignment (ARun) 

Supply assignment ensures that the supply is assigned to the orders according to the changing requirements. Supply protection is only a virtual demand and doesn‚Äôt have a direct relationship to supply elements. Quantities which are assigned via supply assignment are not considered as available quantities in PAC. Settings in supply assignment can be used to respect or overrule restrictions defined by Supply Protection. 

Links: 

  • Community Blog: Supply Protection in Supply Assignment(ARun) 
  • SAP Help: Supply Protection in Supply Assignment 

Related Links: 

  • SAP Community Blog: Supply Protection in a Nutshell  
  • FAQ-Document: 3141787 - FAQ - Supply Protection (SUP) with advanced ATP

entry.title: Clean Core Extensibility: Balancing Standardization and Differentiation
entry.content:
Unlock Agility and Stability with a Clean Core

In today‚Äôs fast-paced digital landscape, organizations need both agility to innovate and stability to grow sustainably. The key to balancing these goals is a clean digital core ‚Äî an ERP foundation that stays standardized, upgrade-stable, and ready for innovation.
But keeping your core clean doesn‚Äôt mean giving up differentiation. It means being deliberate ‚Äî extending only where it creates true business value and competitive advantage.
This is the essence of Clean Core Extensibility.

Clean Core Extensibility: Balancing Standardization and Differentiation

The SAP Business Suite brings this vision to life by unifying ERP and line-of-business applications on a common data foundation with embedded AI and SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) for extensibility. Together, these capabilities enable organizations to connect and optimize every function across the enterprise, ensuring that innovation remains upgrade-stable and grounded in reliable, trusted data.

SAP‚Äôs clean core strategy is built on five guiding principles ‚Äî Processes, Extensibility, Data, Integrations, and Operations. In this blog, we focus on the Extensibility principle, exploring how organizations can innovate safely and strategically while maintaining a standardized, upgrade-stable foundation.

The five guiding principles of a clean core

1. Why You Need a Clean Core ‚Äì and the New Extensibility Model

A clean core is the foundation of a modern cloud ERP strategy. It runs on standardized, upgrade-friendly configurations that minimize technical debt and maximize agility.

A clean core ensures:

  • Faster innovation through seamless cloud updates
  • Lower TCO and reduced complexity
  • Business agility through modular, composable extensions

While the clean core provides stability, extensibility defines how you tailor the system to your needs ‚Äî without losing upgradeability. To enable innovation without sacrificing stability, SAP introduced an evolved Extensibility Model ‚Äî separating standard ERP capabilities from custom innovations.

This cloud-first, modular approach allows extensions to live outside the core while connecting seamlessly to it.
It enables organizations to:

  • Build innovations safely on SAP BTP
  • Adopt continuous updates without disruption
  • Keep systems clean, stable, and flexible

The goal is simple: empower business differentiation while maintaining standardization at the core.

2. Strategic Extensibility in Practice: Extending and Applying the Model

Not all extensions add value ‚Äî and not all differentiation requires custom code. True extensibility is strategic: focus on what drives growth, efficiency, or customer experience. Adopt best practices for core business processes, and customize only when it creates measurable advantage.

SAP‚Äôs evolved Extensibility Model emphasizes decoupling extensions from the standard. By leveraging SAP Build, organizations can implement both on-stack (ABAP Cloud) and side-by-side (BTP) extensions, enabling key users and developers to innovate without modifying the SAP core. This approach ensures easier upgrades, better maintainability, and preserves upgrade stability.

Follow SAP‚Äôs extensibility levels to maintain a clean core:

  1. Adopt a BTP-first mindset ‚Äì Use SAP Build on SAP BTP for custom logic, integrations, and innovation.
  2. Prefer Level A/B extensions: Level A - on-stack or side-by-side via released APIs, Level B - Making use of Classic APIs
  3. Use Level C (utilization of SAP-internal objects) only when absolutely necessary and apply the changelog.
  4. Avoid Level D and continuously refactor legacy code ‚Äì Move unused extensions out of the core.

This structured approach helps organizations balance standardization and differentiation, ensuring a clean core that is robust, adaptable, and ready for innovation.

Guidance for SAP‚Äôs extensibility levels

3. Measuring Your Clean Core with RISE with SAP Methodology: The Clean Core Measurement Framework

Maintaining a clean core is an ongoing process. The Clean Core Measurement Framework helps organizations assess their governance and maturity, define target actions, and track progress through clean core KPIs.

The Governance and Maturity assessment evaluates the tooling, governance, and know-how required to get and stay clean. It calculates a current score for each clean core dimension and can be performed at any stage ‚Äî before, during, or after transformation. Based on this, customers can define a target score aligned with their strategic goals. These criteria and assessments are fully embedded in the RISE with SAP Methodology.

Clean core KPIs complement this by measuring adherence during both implementation and operations. Derived from system data, these KPIs provide automated, transparent insights ‚Äî fully visible in the RISE with SAP Methodology Dashboard.

Together, these measurements create visibility and accountability ‚Äî helping organizations stay on track toward a truly clean core.

entry.title: Oversized Requirements? Here's how to fix them.
entry.content:
Getting requirement sizing right is an important but less obvious driver of predictable SAP project delivery. It is the art of making requirements neither too big nor too small. This may sound like a detail, but it shapes everything that follows: how releases are planned, how work is owned, and how testing stays traceable. After formulation and classification standards, it is another dimension to properly creating requirements.

Why requirements granularity is important?

Granularity defines how big or small a requirement should be so that it can be delivered, tested, and accepted within a single delivery or release cycle.

On one hand, if requirements are too large, their delivery will stretch across waves. This means that one requirement will not be fully completed and fully tested within one Wave release. That breaks the flow of delivery and the traceability of results.

On the other hand, if requirements are too small, the requirements backlog swells with too many tiny items which adds administration effort and slows down the work.

The golden rule

SAP Activate recommends sizing requirements so they can be fully delivered and tested within a single Wave and inside one Work Package. This makes tracking progress from requirement through configuration to test case much easier.

To keep delivery predictable, adopt a simple rule: One Requirement ‚Üí One Work Package ‚Üí One Test Case ‚Üí One Wave

 Decomposition and Grouping

Use early Explore workshops for iterative refinement which is continuously splitting or regrouping requirements as delivery planning evolves.

If a requirement is too large, decompose it into smaller, independent, testable sub-requirements. Each should deliver a clear, standalone piece of value that can be tested independently. They still can be associated with each other in the same test plan.

If a requirement is too small, group it with other closely related requirements and reformulate them into one coherent requirement delivered as one work package.

The effort pays off: proper sizing makes ownership clear, simpler planning, and complete test traceability from requirement to configuration and testing results.

Iterative refinement

Skipping granularity refinement often leaves oversized requirements that may span two waves. This reduces transparency, complicates test coverage, and makes progress reporting unreliable. Right-sized requirements make governance measurable: every item in the backlog has a clear boundary, a single owner, and a defined success criteria.

Iterative refinement

Skipping granularity refinement often leaves oversized requirements that may span two waves. This reduces transparency, complicates test coverage, and makes progress reporting unreliable. Right-sized requirements make governance measurable: every item in the backlog has a clear boundary, a single owner, and a defined success criteria.

Jira practice

Granularity can be managed directly in Jira by defining clear parent‚Äìchild relationships between Requirements and their Deliverables. This approach keeps ownership, scheduling, and testing transparent.

  • Create each main Requirement as a standard level work item

  • In case of need for a decomposition, add sub-task level work items called Sub-Requirements underneath.

  • Map each Requirement or Sub-Requirement to a single Work Package that will be scheduled in one Wave to preserve traceability.

  • Link every requirement to the corresponding Jira Xray Test Cases that verify acceptance and completion.

 You can visualize the hierarchy using a Jira app such as Structure, to display dependencies and delivery scope clearly

 What‚Äôs in it for you?

Requirements granularity may sound like a technical detail, but in SAP projects it‚Äôs one of the strongest predictors of delivery stability. In simple terms, your project scheduling will be much more reliable.

So, next time before you approve a requirement in your backlog, ask: "Will this fit into one Wave, in one Work Package, tested by one Test Case?" If yes, go to the next requirement.
